abstract.p: With the widespread application of meta-analysis, it is important to examine the role of meta-analysis in the development of knowledge. Researchers have proposed that meta-analysis provides us with an overview of where the research field has been, summarizes and integrates extant research findings, and suggests directions for future research efforts. Some researchers further argue that meta-analysis can contribute to the accumulation of knowledge and the progress of science. In this article, these claims are examined from an epistemological perspective. Using Kuhn’s (1962, 1970b) framework, the authors discuss how meta-analysis contributes to the progress of both normal science and extraordinary science and thus plays an important role in knowledge development in a field.

body.p: Meta-analysis refers to an “analysis of analyses” (Glass, 1976) and is suitable for analyzing the results of multiple studies (Schmidt, 1996). Since Glass coined the term in the late 1970s, the use and application of meta-analysis has proliferated (Dalton & Dalton, 2008; Guzzo, Jackson, & Katzell, 1987; Hunt, 1997; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Schulze, 2004). Indeed, meta-analysis has been applied in numerous fields—for example, psychology, law, management, education, medicine, and even policy formulation (Baas, De Dreu, & Nijstad, 2008; Becker, 2001; Dalton & Dalton, 2008; Egger, Smith, & Phillips, 1997; Egger, Smith, Schneider, & Minder, 1997; Gerber & Wheeler, 2009; Hunter & Schmidt, 1996, 2004; Kendall & Maruyama, 1985; Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003; Schmidt, 1992; Steblay, Dysart, & Wells, 2011; Van den Bussche, Van den Noortgate, & Reynvoet, 2009).

Across various fields, meta-analysis has been used to examine (a) the strength of relationship between two variables (e.g., Ilies, Nahrgang, & Morgeson, 2007), (b) the effectiveness of treatments or interventions (e.g., Arthur, Bennett, Edens, & Bell, 2003; Lipsey & Wilson, 1993), (c) the accuracy of theories (e.g., Fried & Ferris’s, 1987, test of the job characteristics model; Rudolph, Roesch, Greitemeyer, & Weiner’s, 2004, test of Weiner’s theory of social conduct; Carlson, Charlin, & Miller’s, 1988, meta-analysis to examine which of six theories accounted for the positive mood-helping relationship), (d) the validity of measuring instruments (e.g., Garb, Florio, & Grove’s, 1998, meta-analysis on the Rorschach inkblot method and the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory; Kinicki, McKee-Ryan, Schriesheim, & Carson’s, 2002, meta-analysis on the Job Descriptive Index), (e) the validity of procedures (Gaugler, Rosenthal, Thornton III, & Bentson’s, 1987, test of assessment center validity; Westerman, Spies, Stahl, & Hesse’s, 1996, test of the validity of mood induction procedures), and (f) the presence of moderation effects (e.g., Donovan & Radosevicb, 1998; Wallace, Paulson, Lord, & Bond, 2005). With such widespread use of meta-analysis, how this methodology affects research and contributes to knowledge growth in a field warrants greater understanding. This article addresses this question.

In the sections that follow, we first discuss the advantages and limitations of meta-analysis before turning to the purposes and functions of meta-analysis. Finally, we explicate how, by contributing to the progress of both normal science and extraordinary science, meta-analysis plays an important role in the development of knowledge.

sec.title: What Meta-Analysis Offers Compared With Single Studies
sec.p: To conduct a meta-analysis, researchers collate extant studies pertaining to a variable (which, for the sake of brevity, may refer to a construct, phenomenon, procedure, treatment, or intervention program) and its relationship with other variables and then summarize these relationships statistically. Essentially, from the summary statistics of the primary research studies (e.g., F, t, means, standard deviations), a meta-analysis computes an average effect size estimate (r or d) to provide an overview of the findings in a particular area of research (Glass, McGaw, & Smith, 1981; Hedges & Olkin, 1985; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004). Researchers have developed various meta-analytic methods over the years—for fuller descriptions of these methods, see Hedges and Olkin (1985); Rosenthal (1984); Raju, Burke, Normand, and Langlois (1991); Callender and Osburn (1980); Glass et al. (1981); as well as Hunter and Schmidt (2004).

Whatever the method adopted, the use of meta-analysis techniques has several purported advantages over primary studies. First, by incorporating data drawn from many primary studies, meta-analytic studies include much larger sample sizes. This offers reduced sampling error and increased precision around the overall mean effect (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004). Second, meta-analysis allows researchers to adjust for other artifacts that may influence effect size. For example, researchers can adjust or correct for measurement error, imperfect construct validity of measures, and range restriction, as well as the artificial dichotomization of continuous measures (Hedges & Olkin, 1985; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Schmidt, 2010). We note, of course, that this particular advantage is not unique to meta-analytic methods; primary research studies may also adjust for such artifacts before conducting their substantive analyses or interpreting their results. However, these adjustments are more accurate for meta-analyses than for primary studies because the larger sample sizes in meta-analytic studies lead to less sampling error variance around the adjusted estimates. Indeed, adjusting for artifacts within a meta-analysis enables researchers to obtain more precise and accurate estimates of the true relationships between variables of interest.

Third, meta-analysis allows researchers to explore research possibilities and test more comprehensive research models that have not been examined in individual primary studies (Eden, 2002; Rothstein 2003; Zimmerman, 2008). For example, Zimmerman (2008) incorporated meta-analytic estimates (i.e., results of true-score correlation estimates from other relevant meta-analytic studies) into his correlation matrix in order to conduct a path analysis to test a large model of employee turnover. Meta-analysis also allows one to examine which factors account for the underlying regularities and variations across multiple studies conducted within a field (i.e., between studies)—issues that cannot be investigated if a single study approach is used (Rothstein, 2003). For example, Fehr and colleagues (Fehr, Gelfand, & Nag, 2010) investigated whether study methodology (recall versus scenario methods) may be a significant between-study moderator of results in their meta-analysis on the various correlates of forgiveness.

However, like all methodologies, meta-analysis is not without its limitations. First, there is an element of subjectivity involved as researchers need to make multiple judgment calls in the course of conducting a meta-analysis (e.g., judgment calls on what statistical formulae to use, which articles to include or exclude in a meta-analysis; see Guzzo et al., 1987; Wanous, Sullivan, & Malinak, 1989). Thus, it is important to ensure that such judgment calls are transparently reported. Second, in order to compute effect size estimates, meta-analysis can include only those primary studies that report certain statistics (e.g., the F, t, means, and standard deviations; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004). This calls the representativeness of the primary studies into question since they may not all include the required statistics information (Guzzo et al., 1987). Third, unless meta-analysts are careful to avoid the “file-drawer” problem, publication bias may lead to a bias in the selection of primary studies, resulting in an overestimation of the strength of relationship between variables (Lae & Crano, 2009; Lipsey & Wilson, 1993). Despite these concerns, meta-analysis continues to be widely used. One possible reason for its continuing popularity is that alternative methods for reviewing research literature encounter similar problems. For example, qualitative narrative reviews similarly entail great degrees of subjectivity with regard to the selection of articles, and they similarly encounter the “file-drawer” problem (Rosenthal & Rosnow, 2008; Sharpe, 1997). Thus, compared with its alternatives, meta-analysis’s limitations are not particularly detrimental.

sec.title: Purpose of Meta-Analysis
sec.p: Even though meta-analysis enjoys widespread application, researchers have differing opinions about the ultimate purpose of meta-analysis (Hunter & Schmidt, 2004)—especially with regard to the role of meta-analysis in the advancement of knowledge. Some researchers argue that meta-analysis merely provides a description and summary review of extant studies in a field (e.g., Glass, 1976; Glass et al., 1981; Guzzo et al., 1987; Hoyle, 1993; Sohn, 1996) but is not ideally suited for theory development and scientific discovery (e.g., Chow, 1987; Guzzo et al., 1987; Hoyle, 1993; Lepper, 1995; Sohn, 1995, 1996). For example, questions are raised on whether a meta-analysis exerts a “chilling effect” on the number of primary studies conducted after it has been published (Slavin, 1984). As Slavin (1984) expressed, “I feel a serious danger posed by the widespread use of meta-analysis is that it may discourage further research in the area synthesized” (p. 13).

Yet other researchers counterargue that a “chilling effect” may be expedient if research in a topic (or field) has been saturated or when sufficient research has triangulated onto some conclusion on the topic (Mullen, Muellerleile, & Bryant, 2001; Murphy & Newman, 2003; Schmidt, 1992; Schmidt et al., 1985). For example, there is already a substantial amount of research on the relationship between perceptual speed and job performance that has been summarized in a meta-analysis (Pearlman, Schmidt, & Hunter, 1980). Because we now have good understanding of this relationship, it would be judicious not to further dedicate scarce resources to this line of work and to instead allocate these resources to more productive endeavors (Schmidt et al., 1985). Similarly, researchers have noted that additional research on the relationship between cognitive ability and job performance may not be very useful since meta-analytic studies have consistently demonstrated this relationship across various settings, organizations, and job types (Murphy & Newman, 2003). Given the useful role that meta-analysis plays in this regard, the more important question, therefore, is whether meta-analysis subverts researchers’ motivation to conduct primary research studies when the research in a field is not yet saturated (i.e., when researchers have not completely discovered the answers to the questions in a field; or when the results of a meta-analysis show that findings in a field do not converge onto a conclusion). Indeed, as Hale and Dillard have commented, “we need to be careful that meta-analyses do not end lines of research prematurely” (1991, p. 466).

Whereas detractors argue that meta-analysis has little role in the important work of theory development and scientific discovery, supporters of the method see it as crucial to the development of knowledge and theory in a field (Franke, 2001; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Miller & Pollock, 1995; Rothstein, 2003; Schmidt, 1992; Schulze, 2004). Supporters of meta-analysis argue that the method is more than just a means of summarizing bivariate relationships; rather, it informs us where the field has been, and it integrates or synthesizes extant empirical studies in the field (Eden, 2002; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Kendall & Maruyama, 1985). Such synthesis further facilitates interpretation as it “cleans up the field” (Schmidt, 1992) and provides suggestions for future research (Franke, 2001; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Kendall & Maruyama, 1985).

Supporters of meta-analysis further posit that given that the purpose of science is to accumulate knowledge and to provide theoretical development (e.g., Curran, 2009; Schmidt, 1992), the examination of whether the findings across research studies in a field are homogeneous is an important step in the accumulation of such knowledge—and meta-analysis is useful in this regard (Schmidt, 1992). For example, very often, some studies in a field report that a relationship between a focal construct and another variable is statistically significant, while others find the relationship to be nonsignificant. On their own, these seemingly contradictory findings stifle the accumulation of knowledge and impede the progress of psychological science (Cohen, 1994; Schmidt, 1996). However, applying meta-analysis to the results of these studies demonstrates that much of the variation across studies is due to sampling error (Richard et al., 2003; Schmidt, 1992) and that the study results are actually quite homogeneous after sampling error is partialed out. Therefore, meta-analysis helps to remedy the false appearance of conflicting findings and contributes to the accumulation of knowledge (Schmidt, 1992, 1996).

Second, supporters of meta-analysis posit that meta-analysis is crucial for the development of knowledge and theory in a field as it provides the building blocks for such endeavors (Schmidt, 1992). Specifically, quantifying the existence, strength, and variability of relationships among variables will equip researchers with the knowledge to build theories with regard to their focal variables or relationships (Schmidt, 1992). Indeed, Hunter and Schmidt (2004) posit that the purpose of their meta-analytic method is to estimate the true effect size of the relationships between variables at the construct level and then to use these estimates as the ingredients to inform theory development. Further, meta-analytically derived estimates of the relationships among the variables or constructs of interest allow theories of causal models to be tested using path analysis or structural equation modeling (SEM; Rudolph et al., 2004; Schmidt, 1992; Zimmerman, 2008). Although path analysis and SEM cannot provide information about whether a particular research model is correct, they can inform us as to whether a model is incorrect and therefore assist in the elimination of incorrect models from the research landscape. This is a significant step in the accumulation of knowledge and the progress of science (Schmidt, 1992).

Third, meta-analysis contributes to the advancement of knowledge in a field by providing researchers with basic information so that they may strategically plan future studies and judiciously allocate resources toward more fruitful avenues of research (Eden, 2002; Hunter & Schmidt, 2004; Schmidt, 1992). Several researchers have credited meta-analysis for setting the direction for research efforts in a field (e.g., Rothstein, 2003). For example, when large variations in effect sizes persist after sampling error and other research artifacts have been controlled for, the existence of moderators is suggested (Rosenthal & DiMatteo, 2001), and the search for plausible moderators of the focal independent-variable–dependent- variable meta-analyzed relationship becomes a fruitful avenue for subsequent research. Indeed, Rothstein (2003) argued that follow-up studies that are based on the results of meta-analysis contribute more to knowledge growth than follow-up studies based on the results of other primary studies.

sec.title: The Role of Meta-Analysis in Knowledge Growth: An Epistemological Perspective
sec.p: Although the role of meta-analysis in knowledge growth has been discussed, no known study has examined these claims from an epistemological perspective. Indeed, to address the concern of whether meta-analysis “end[s] lines of research prematurely” (Hale & Dillard, 1991, p. 466), it is instructive to examine how knowledge and science grow. Largely predicated on Kuhn’s (1962, 1970b) framework of scientific development, our proposed framework explicates the role of meta-analysis in the progress of knowledge and science. Before exploring knowledge growth produced by meta-analysis, we first introduce the notion of paradigm, which is a central concept in Kuhn’s framework.

sec.title: Kuhn’s paradigms
sec.p: Kuhn (1962, 1970b) used the term paradigm in two senses. First, the term is used in a broad sense to refer to “the entire constellation of beliefs, values, techniques and so on shared by members of a given community” (Kuhn, 1970b, p. 175). Using this broad conceptualization, Kuhn (1970b) also referred to paradigm as a “disciplinary matrix,” which includes symbolic generalizations, models, values, and exemplary problem solutions. The second, more narrow, use of the term paradigm refers to exemplars or exemplary problem-solutions—one of the elements within his disciplinary matrix (Kuhn, 1970b). In this article, we take a conservative approach and adopt Kuhn’s (1970b) broad-based paradigm definition because (a) all the elements in Kuhn’s disciplinary matrix are inseparable and thus should be considered as a whole, and (b) even the narrower use of the term paradigm as exemplars would incorporate the other elements of Kuhn’s disciplinary matrix (e.g., symbolic generalizations, models; see Hoyningen-Huene, 1993). Hence, in this article, a paradigm refers to a framework of beliefs, values, and techniques that informs researchers in their generation, development, and application of knowledge (Kuhn, 1970b.

According to Kuhn (1962), the notion of paradigm permeates all aspects of scientific endeavors in a field—from an existing paradigm, researchers develop theory and hypotheses; even methodologies are developed from the existing paradigm. Indeed, the paradigm that is held by the community of researchers also determines what the legitimate questions to be asked are. Correspondingly, the search for solutions to a phenomenon of interest is also guided by the existing paradigm (Kuhn, 1962).

We illustrate the notion of paradigm with concrete examples from mainstream psychology—behaviorism and cognitivism. Under the behaviorist paradigm (which dominated U.S. psychology from the 1930s to the 1960s), psychology is a science of behaviors rather than a science of the mind and consciousness, and the goal of research is to predict and control behaviors (Watson, 1913). Because of the belief that only the study of observable concepts (i.e., behaviors) is truly scientific, the primary methodology of the behaviorist was the examination of objective observable behavior in the laboratory; introspection, the prevailing methodology of its mentalist predecessor, was considered unscientific and not a legitimate methodology (Watson, 1913). Moreover, because the focus was on observable behaviors (with concepts like mental states and processes deemed either irrelevant or peripheral), the use of animal subjects to examine behaviors in the laboratory was an acceptable and widely shared practice (Benjamin, 2009; Fuchs & Milar, 2003; King, Viney, & Woody, 2009; Leahey, 2003; Mandler, 2002; Secord, 1977; Segal & Lachman, 1972). Even the behaviorists’ language demonstrated this paradigm, as their language revolved around the “stimulus-response” concept.

Conversely, the cognitivism paradigm attained popularity largely from the 1970s onward (Leahey, 2004; Robins, Gosling, & Craik, 1999). In contrast to the behaviorists, cognitivists held the belief that the study of the unobservable human mind, mental states, and processes is legitimate (as information—a central concept in the cognitivist paradigm—is also unobservable; Leahey, 2004). In fact, cognitivists were concerned with understanding how humans process information (Leahey, 2003, 2004). Moreover, cognitivists used computers (e.g., computer simulations) rather than animal subjects in their methodologies, and the language of the cognitivists was couched in “input– output” or “input–processing–output” terms (Benjamin, 2009; King et al., 2009; Leahey, 2004).

sec.title: The development of mature science
sec.p: Using these two paradigms (i.e., behaviorism and cognitivism) as illustrations, one can see how paradigms guide research endeavors within a field.1 Next, we summarize Kuhn’s (1962, 1970b) description of how the mature physical sciences develop. First, sciences start off in an immature stage. At this stage, there are typically many competing schools of thought, and debates are rife among the various schools over the fundamentals in the field. Because no one paradigm is shared by the community of researchers, no paradigm systematically directs the collective research endeavors within the field.

However, at some point, a paradigm emerges as the “winner” and becomes the dominant paradigm in its field. In general, this dominant paradigm provides better explanations and predictions about the phenomenon of interest than its competitors. With the dominant paradigm being shared and accepted by the community of researchers as the guiding framework for their research endeavors, the field makes the transition from an immature science to a mature science (Kuhn, 1970b).

Once a dominant paradigm is shared throughout a research community, a period of “normal science” ensues. According to Kuhn, normal science refers to “research firmly based upon one or more past scientific achievements, achievements that some particular scientific community acknowledges for a time as supplying the foundation for its further practice” (Kuhn, 1962, p. 10). Research during the normal science period is likened to puzzle solving. In normal science, the paradigm guides and directs research activities—specifically, the paradigm determines what the legitimate puzzle questions are, the means of searching for puzzle solutions, and the standards with which to evaluate puzzle solutions. In fact, the main aim in normal science is the further articulation of the paradigm—to increase the precision and scope of the paradigm (Kuhn, 1962).

In contrast to the immature science stage, normal science is depicted as a period in which members of a research community are no longer compelled to argue and justify the fundamentals repeatedly as there exists a consensus among researchers. Thus, researchers can assume the fundamentals in the field and move on to more esoteric aspects of research. Indeed, research progresses more efficiently during the normal science period (Kuhn, 1970a).

Although researchers in the normal science period are not primarily engaged in seeking out anomalies or falsifying theories (Popper, 1959), some anomalies and falsifications may emerge (Kuhn, 1970a). When an anomaly first appears, it is typically the reputation of the researcher (rather than the existing paradigm) that is in question. However, if anomalies persist and cannot be solved by even the most brilliant minds in the field, then a crisis is precipitated. Of course, not all anomalies will produce a crisis (Hoyningen-Huene, 1993). Generally, only critical anomalies that pertain to the core of the paradigm will precipitate a crisis. During a crisis, the rules of normal science loosen as researchers’ search for answers move increasingly further away from the existing paradigm (because it does not adequately account for the anomalies; Kuhn, 1962).

During this period of crisis and revolutions (also referred to as “extraordinary science”), philosophical debates about the fundamentals in the field are again rife, and alternative paradigms emerge in an effort to address the anomalies. These alternate paradigms, as well as the preexisting paradigm, compete for the allegiance of the research community. Because the competing paradigms are incommensurable with one another, the choice of one paradigm over others cannot proceed via logic or proof; rather, persuasion is the process with which the allegiance of the researchers is won (Kuhn, 1970a). Over time, an increasing proportion of the research community subscribes to the new alternate paradigm. Finally, the research community is converted to a (alternate) paradigm, and the paradigm becomes the new dominant paradigm in the field. At this juncture, the revolution is complete, and a paradigm shift has occurred in the field. A new period of normal science then ensues, with the new paradigm serving as the guiding framework for the research community. In general, the new paradigm has been adopted because it can resolve the anomalies and account for most of the research puzzle solutions that the preexisting paradigm had solved in the past and also because it holds greater promise for guiding research in the future than does the preexisting paradigm.

Sometimes, though, the extant paradigm (i.e., the paradigm that existed before the crisis) eventually comes to handle the anomalies such that they cease to be a problem—for example, the theory can be modified to incorporate the “anomaly” such that it becomes expected or eliminated within the modified version. In this case, there will not be a paradigm shift, and another phase of normal science will ensue instead—with the extant paradigm remaining as the dominant paradigm that guides research activities in the field. In sum, science progresses through periods of normal and extraordinary science—that is, through periods of traditional paradigm-based research, punctuated by periods of paradigm-shattering research (Kuhn, 1962).

sec.title: Meta-Analysis and Normal Science
sec.p: How does meta-analysis play a role in the progress of normal science and knowledge growth? First, in order for a meta-analysis to be conducted, a corpus of primary studies must exist (Lipsey & Wilson, 1993). Because the primary studies are conducted within an existing paradigm and meta-analysis uses the results of these studies as units of analysis (Bullock & Svyantek, 1985; Sackett, Harris, & Orr, 1986), a meta-analytic study will be couched within an existing paradigm. In fact, meta-analysis can be conducted only when a paradigm exists. In the following paragraphs, we explicate several ways in which meta-analysis contributes to the progress of normal science.

sec.title: Stocktaking and strategically guiding future research
sec.p: First, meta-analysis allows researchers to take stock of whether and how well the paradigmatically derived questions have been answered. Taking stock of the puzzle-solving enterprise is important to the progress of science as it is necessary to know the current state of knowledge and where the field has been in order to move strategically in future research endeavors (Sackett, 2003). To elaborate, meta-analysis can guide and suggest future research and point to further theoretical questions (Czienskowski, 2003). Indeed, meta-analytic researchers often offer recommendations based on the results of their meta-analysis, and the progress of knowledge may potentially be furthered when researchers heed such recommendations.

For example, Gerstner and Day (1997) conducted a meta-analysis on the leader-member exchange (LMX) variable, which refers to a dyadic relationship between a leader and his or her subordinate. According to LMX theory, leaders form different relationships with their subordinates, such that they have close relationships with some subordinates and distant relationships with others (Bauer & Green, 1996). The meta-analysis indicated that among the various LMX measures in the literature, LMX-7 had the best psychometric properties. Did future researchers heed this note and choose to use LMX-7 over other LMX measures?

To investigate this question, we conducted a brief content analysis of published empirical studies on the topic of LMX. A total of 230 published empirical studies were obtained, of which 186 were published after 1997, and 44 were published in or before 1997. Two undergraduate raters (interrater reliability = .79) who were unaware of our study’s hypothesis coded each article based on whether the researchers had used the (full) LMX-7 measure for their study. The content analysis showed that after Gerstner and Day’s (1997) LMX meta-analysis, a greater percentage (58.9%) of published empirical studies employed the LMX-7 measure than before the meta-analysis (28.4%), z = 3.64, p < .05. Of the post-1997 published empirical studies that employed the LMX-7 measure, 61.2% cited Gerstner and Day’s (1997) LMX meta-analysis article. These results suggest that many post-1997 researchers heeded Gerstner and Day’s recommendation to use the LMX-7 measure for their own studies.

That said, we add the caveat here that because this LMX-7 example constitutes only a single case study and data point, we cannot fully say to what extent researchers generally heed meta-analytic studies’ recommendation. In fact, Maruyama (1991) noted that many researchers investigating the relationship between goal structure and achievement after 1981 did not heed the “best bets” that Johnson and colleagues’ (Johnson, Maruyama, Johnson, Nelson, & Skon, 1981) meta-analytic study generated. Although Maruyama’s (1991) example shows that researchers do not always follow up on a meta-analysis’s advice or recommendations, this does not refute our suggestion that future researchers’ adoption of meta-analytically based recommendations may be a potential way in which meta-analysis strategically contributes to knowledge growth in a field.

sec.title: Increasing the precision of a paradigm
sec.p: Second, meta-analysis contributes to the progress of normal science by playing a vital role in mopping-up operations (Kuhn, 1962)—which refer to operations that can help to increase the precision of a paradigm and match the paradigm ever more closely with nature. Mopping-up operations include efforts to clarify the nature of the construct and the construct validity of its measurement, clarify the nature and strength of the relationship between variables, and investigate moderating factors that may influence the relationship of interest. We elaborate on each mopping-up operation in turn.

sec.title: Clarifying the construct and its measures
sec.p: First, meta-analysis can help clarify the nature of a construct and the construct validity of its measure. For example, LePine and colleagues (LePine, Erez, & Johnson, 2002) used meta-analysis to clarify the nature of the organizational citizenship behavior (OCB) construct, which refers to “individual behavior that is discretionary, not directly or explicitly recognized by the formal reward system, and that in the aggregate promotes the effective functioning of the organization” (Organ, 1988, p. 4). LePine et al. found that Organ’s (1988) five OCB subdimensions were strongly related to one another and had similar relationships with attitudinal predictors. These results suggested that a single global OCB construct is operative (LePine et al., 2002). In this study, meta-analysis clarified the nature of the construct and thus helped to increase the precision of the paradigm.

As mentioned earlier, methodology is an important aspect of a paradigm as well. Thus, a way to increase the precision of a paradigm is to ensure or even increase the validity of a measure (especially the construct validity of a measure). Meta-analysis can also be useful to this end as it helps researchers to clarify construct validity issues. For example, a meta-analysis on achievement goals revealed that there are construct validity problems in extant achievement-goal research (Hulleman, Schrager, Bodmann, & Harackiewicz, 2010). The meta-analysis showed that the measurement items that were presumed to tap mastery-approach goals did not in fact contain any goal-relevant language. This finding led the authors to question whether these items actually assess the mastery-approach goal orientation. Furthermore, this meta-analysis also showed that the use of different achievement-goal measures in different studies yielded different results. The fact that different achievement-goal measures moderated the substantive results has serious implications for achievement-goal research—leading essentially to problems in theory testing and development on this topic (Hulleman et al., 2010). By diagnosing the construct validity problems in the field, this meta-analysis helped to increase the precision of achievement-goal paradigm and research.

sec.title: Clarifying the relationship between variables
sec.p: Another kind of mopping-up operation that increases the precision of a paradigm is the clarification of the nature and strength of the relationship between two variables. For example, Dalal (2005) used meta-analysis to clarify the relationship between OCB and counterproductive work behavior (CWB, which refers to voluntary employee behaviors that are detrimental to the well-being of an organization—for example, damaging company equipment, deliberately producing low-quality work, aggressing against one’s coworkers). Dalal’s study showed that there is a negative relationship between OCB and CWB; furthermore, OCB and CWB have differential patterns and magnitudes of relationships with various antecedents. These results clarify that OCB and CWB are not opposite poles on a single dimension; rather, OCB and CWB are distinct constructs (Dalal, 2005).

sec.title: Finding mediators
sec.p: Furthermore, after a meta-analysis establishes the nature and strength of relationship between two variables, researchers may then fruitfully proceed to investigate potential mediators between these two variables. As mediation tests provide insight into the underlying mechanism through which variables operate to affect one another, they are thus an important tool for theory development (Miller & Pollock, 1995; N. P. Podsakoff, Whiting, Podsakoff, & Blume, 2009). This proposition resonates with Kuhn’s (1962) observation that as meta-analysis helps researchers establish some basic truths about the focal variable and its relationships, it frees researchers from having to grapple with these basic truths again, thus allowing them to move on to examine more complex aspects of the paradigm (i.e., mediator testing, in this case; Kuhn, 1962). This will in turn increase the precision and broaden the scope of a paradigm.

sec.title: Finding moderators
sec.p: A third kind of mopping-up operation that can increase the precision of a paradigm involves the investigation of moderating effects. For example, Wallace et al.’s (2005) meta-analysis showed that situational factors (i.e., perceived social pressure) moderated the relationship between attitudes and behavior. As another example, DePaulo and colleagues’ (DePaulo et al., 2003) meta-analytic study revealed that whether people are lying about transgressions versus nontransgressions (i.e., the moderator) affected the strength of deception cues—specifically, people who lie about transgressions are more tense and fidgety, thus providing stronger cues of deception than people who lie about nontransgressions.

Another kind of moderation test involves clarifying the conditions under which a treatment–intervention is most or least effective, as well as the conditions in which the treatment–intervention’s efficacy may be increased or decreased (Matt & Navarro, 1997; Stajkovic & Luthans, 2003). For example, Stajkovic and Luthans’s meta-analytic study showed that behavioral management interventions have the greatest impact on task performance when reinforcers are used in combination. Specifically, when money, feedback, and social recognition are combined, the three reinforcers operate synergistically to produce a positive effect on task performance. Thus, meta-analysis also contributes to increasing the precision of a paradigm by enabling the identification of moderating factors.

sec.title: Broadening the scope of a paradigm
sec.p: Broadening the scope of a paradigm is another objective associated with normal science that we posit that meta-analysis can assist with. One way in which the scope of a paradigm may be broadened is by testing relationships between the focal variable and new variables (Maruyama, 1991). After a meta- analysis, researchers equipped with a better understanding of a variable may investigate previously unexplored relationships between the focal variable and other variables.

Extrapolating meta-analytic findings and testing them on yet untested types of samples, settings, and so forth is another way to broaden the scope of a paradigm’s application. An example from psychotherapy research illustrates this point. Because meta-analysis has a more heterogeneous database than a primary study, it allows researchers to examine the generalizability or robustness of psychotherapy effects across different treatment settings, different samples of patients and therapists, and different types of psychological disorders (Butler, Chapman, Forman, & Beck, 2006; Matt & Navarro, 1997). According to Matt and colleagues (Matt & Cook, 2009; Matt & Navarro, 1997), if a meta-analysis demonstrates that a focal psychotherapy effect is robust across different samples and settings, researchers may have more confidence in extrapolating and hypothesizing that this effect may apply to other yet unstudied samples and settings. If our hypotheses at extrapolation are supported, we would have broadened the scope of a paradigm’s applications.

Another example from the field of social psychology shows the ability of meta-analysis to broaden the scope of a paradigm and its applications. Rudolph et al. (2004) conducted two meta-analyses within a study—one on the determinants of help giving and another on the determinants of aggression. In the study, the authors tested Weiner’s theoretical framework of social conduct (1995), which posits that judgments of responsibility elicit specific emotions, which in turn lead to the behaviors of help giving or aggression. The results of these two meta-analyses show that the framework could be applied to the two different domains of social behavior (i.e., help-giving and aggression domains). This example demonstrates how meta-analysis can help to broaden the scope of a paradigm’s applications.

In addition, because meta-analysis provides researchers with a clearer understanding of the focal variable and more extensively reveals the variety of other variables that are associated with it, future research regarding the focal variable can be situated within a larger nomological network. For example, after a meta-analysis, researchers may test the meta-analyzed relationship within a moderation, mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation model, or simply within a larger model. For example, Zimmerman (2008) used meta-analytic estimates as input into path analysis—this allowed him to test larger models than would have been feasible in a typical primary study. In this way, meta-analysis allows us to broaden the scope of a paradigm and its applications.

sec.title: Consensus building
sec.p: Another way in which meta-analysis may contribute to the advancement of knowledge and normal science is by facilitating the building of consensus in a field or topic. According to Pfeffer’s (1993) article, which is particularly relevant to the normal science phase, consensus is crucial for and is an indicator of the level of paradigm acceptance and development in a field. The level of paradigm development is important because it is positively related to the level of resources (e.g., funding for research projects) that the field will receive, which in turn affects the amount of research and the amount of knowledge accumulated in the field. As knowledge accumulates, the level of development of the paradigm increases, and there is a positive feedback loop between the level of paradigm development and the growth of knowledge in a field. By facilitating the building of consensus in a field (e.g., which can be seen when future researchers cite the results of a meta-analysis or use meta-analytic estimates to build and test larger models), meta-analysis is thus important for paradigm and knowledge development in a field.

An example of how meta-analysis may facilitate consensus building and paradigm development is Fehr et al.’s (2010) meta-analysis on forgiveness research. Currently, forgiveness research spans several subdisciplines in psychology—social psychology, counseling psychology, organizational psychology, and clinical psychology, to name a few. The interdisciplinary nature of forgiveness research may benefit particularly from Fehr et al.’s meta-analysis as their broad theoretical framework on forgiveness (informed by meta-analytic results) provides a common platform that facilitates more effective and productive discussions among researchers from various psychology subdisciplines.

A final example of how meta-analysis can facilitate consensus building and paradigm development pertains to research in the industrial/organizational (I/O) psychology field. In the I/O psychology field, there is currently a proliferation of OCB-like constructs. These include the concepts of OCB (Organ, 1988), contextual performance (Borman & Motowidlo, 1993), organizational spontaneity (George & Brief, 1992), prosocial organizational behavior (Brief & Motowidlo, 1986), and extra-role behavior (Van Dyne, Cummings, & McLean Parks, 1995). Meta-analysis may be used to address this problem of construct proliferation (DeGeest & Schmidt, 2010; Schmidt, 2010). For example, in the case of OCB research, we can conduct meta-analyses on these various OCB-like constructs and examine whether these various constructs are distinct or whether they have similar nomological networks. If the results of the meta-analysis show that these OCB-like constructs have similar nomological networks, then they may be deemed as equivalent constructs (e.g., P. M. Podsakoff, MacKenzie, Paine, & Bachrach, 2000). In this case, we can lower the dispersion of scarce resources and collapse research efforts to facilitate more concentrated research on this topic. This in turn will facilitate an increase in the level of paradigm development and consensus in the field. Thus, meta-analysis can serve as a springboard to build more consensus in the field and ultimately lead to more knowledge growth. In sum, these are some ways in which meta-analysis pushes the knowledge frontier in normal science.

sec.title: Meta-Analysis and Extraordinary Science
sec.p: Although meta-analysis plays an important role in the progress of normal science, it can also lead to crises and revolutions and thus contribute to extraordinary science (Kuhn, 1962). Specifically, meta-analysis illuminates which predictions governed by the extant paradigm are supported and which are not. Predictions that are not supported in a meta-analysis would have been repeatedly falsified (Popper, 1959) because the results were based on numerous studies. In addition, the utilization of multiple studies and larger samples accentuates researchers’ awareness of the anomalies (i.e., predictions that are not supported and unexpected findings).

If defenders of the paradigm are not able to explain these persistent anomalous findings, a crisis may develop within the field, which then becomes an opportunity for a scientific revolution (Bird, 2000; Kuhn, 1962). Yet, Kuhn also observed that when an existing paradigm’s predictions are not supported, the paradigm may not necessarily be aborted—unless a better paradigm has been birthed. That is, researchers usually abandon an existing paradigm when two conditions are met: when there are critical anomalous findings that the existing paradigm cannot reconcile and when there is a new alternate paradigm that (a) is better at explaining the anomalous findings, (b) can explain the bulk of the research phenomena that the existing paradigm had explained, and (c) holds greater promise of guiding future research than the existing paradigm. Thus, although meta-analysis may provide an opportunity for a revolution, it does not necessarily lead to a paradigm shift. Nonetheless, because of its ability to spark off crises and revolutions, meta-analysis can thus contribute to extraordinary science.

An example of a prominent meta-analysis that revealed unexpected findings and garnered a great deal of research attention is Smith and Glass’s (1977) meta-analysis on psychotherapy outcomes. In the introduction of their article, Smith and Glass lamented that “perception that research shows the inefficacy of psychotherapy has become part of conventional wisdom even within the profession” (p. 752). Flying in the face of the then unflattering view of psychotherapy, this meta-analysis demonstrated the efficacy of various psychotherapies. Eyebrows were raised even higher when the meta-analysis showed that there is little difference in the effectiveness of different types of psychotherapy. This finding led Smith and Glass to state that “despite volumes devoted to the theoretical differences among different schools of psychotherapy, the results of research demonstrate negligible differences in the effects produced by different therapy types” (p. 760). This meta-analytic finding subsequently changed the practice of clinical psychology. Specifically, because the various types of psychotherapy were shown to be similarly effective, many practitioner therapists now treat their clients with a variety of therapy methods, instead of committing themselves to only one particular type of psychotherapy (Hock, 2005). Indeed, this led Hock (2005) to cite Smith and Glass’s (1977) article as one of the 40 studies that changed psychology.

Within the field of social psychology, Malle (2006) conducted a meta-analysis on the actor-observer asymmetry (Jones & Nisbett, 1971). Actor-observer asymmetry refers to the phenomenon where actors have a tendency to make situational attributions for their behaviors, while observers have a tendency to make personal or dispositional attributions for actors’ behaviors. However, the results of Malle’s meta-analysis demonstrated that the classic actor-observer asymmetry does not hold and thus called into question Jones and Nisbett’s paradigm—one that had been taken for granted for more than three decades in social psychology. Indeed, prior to this meta-analysis, the actor-observer asymmetry was believed to be robust and firmly established within psychology. In this case, meta-analysis facilitated researchers’ awareness of the anomalies, which may in turn prepare the way for extraordinary science or “set the stage for a new approach to studying how people explain human behavior” (Malle, 2006, p. 914).

As another example, Carlson and Miller (1987) conducted a meta-analysis on the relationship between negative mood states and prosocial behavior and found that Cialdini’s negative state relief (NSR) model (1973) did not account for the negative mood–prosocial behavior findings. In response, Cialdini and Fultz (1990) wrote an article to address Carlson and Miller’s study and defend the NSR model. Subsequently, Miller and Carlson (1990) retorted that they in fact conducted another meta-analysis on the negative mood–prosocial behavior relationship, this time using Cialdini and Fultz’s stipulated criteria for analysis and found that the results supported their original meta-analytic conclusions. Miller and Carlson ended their article by questioning the adequacy of the NSR model since its predictions were repeatedly disconfirmed in the multiple primary studies that comprised the meta-analysis. This example illustrates that a meta-analytic study can generate strong reactions and fierce debate within a field (i.e., Cialdini and Fultz versus Miller and Carlson). The reactions and debate that ensued in this example attest to meta-analysis’s potential to generate crises and revolutions and thus contribute to extraordinary science.

A final example of how meta-analysis contributes to extraordinary science can be drawn from the discipline of I/O psychology. Several meta-analyses have been conducted showing rather conclusively that cognitive ability is related to job performance and that this cognitive ability–performance relationship is generalizable across settings, jobs, and organizations. This research led to the debunking of the more-than-half-a-century-old situational specificity hypothesis (which stated that the variances found among the validities of cognitive tests in predicting job performance were dependent on contextual features such as subtle nuances in job and job type, industry, and so forth; Schmidt et al., 1985; Schmidt et al., 1993; Schmidt & Hunter, 2003). This paradigm shift had a major impact on the thinking and practice in I/O psychology (Landy, 2003; Murphy & Newman, 2003; Rothstein, 2003). These various examples thus illustrate meta-analysis’s role in contributing to extraordinary science.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In summary, we have explicated in the above sections how meta-analysis, by helping to increase the precision and scope of a paradigm, contributes to the progress of normal science. We have explained also that meta-analysis facilitates researchers’ awareness of anomalies in a field and, in doing so, that it plays a key role in sparking scientific crises and revolutions, thus also contributing to the progress of extraordinary science. Indeed, the seeds of a revolution are contained within the existing paradigm (Kuhn, 1962)—meta-analysis helps reveal these seeds.

The foregoing discussion is largely predicated on Kuhn’s (1962) framework of scientific progress. Yet one may observe that although Kuhn’s account of scientific development has enjoyed much popularity (Driver-Linn, 2003), it is not without its critics. For example, some have argued that there may not in fact be such a sharp dichotomy between normal and extraordinary science—there may instead be a continuum of changes in paradigms within a scientific field (Bird, 2000). Indeed, Laudan (1984) further argued that a paradigm need not change as a whole—it may instead change in a piecemeal fashion. However, these critiques have little implication for our account of how meta-analysis contributes to scientific progress as our account implicitly incorporates and thus addresses all magnitudes of change (e.g., Smith & Glass’s, 1977, meta-analysis brought about big changes; Carlson & Miller’s, 1987, meta-analysis brought about small changes). Thus, in the following paragraphs, we elaborate only on the criticism of Kuhn’s framework that may pertain to our discourse on how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth.

Researchers have critiqued Kuhn’s proposition that only one dominant paradigm operates during the normal science period of a mature science. Indeed, well-known philosophers have argued that multiple paradigms can and have coexisted simultaneously even for the mature sciences (Lakatos, 1970; Laudan, 1977; Popper, 1970). Although it is not the aim of this article to resolve the philosophical debate over whether mature sciences have single or multiple paradigms at any one point in time, we will extend our discussion to a scenario where multiple paradigms coexist during the normal science period of a mature scientific field (although this may stretch Kuhn’s framework beyond his recognition). Specifically, we posit that in the case where multiple paradigms coexist during the normal science period, within each paradigm, the main aim and activities of Kuhn’s normal science period (i.e., traditional paradigm-based research) still apply. That is, even in the case where multiple paradigms coexist in the normal science period, researchers within each paradigm are still engaged in activities with the aim to further articulate the paradigm—to increase the precision and scope of the paradigm they work with. Applied to our discourse on how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth, our proposed ways in which meta-analysis contributes to normal science—stocktaking and strategically guiding future research, mopping-up operations that increase the precision of the paradigm, building consensus within a paradigm, and broadening the scope of the paradigm—would still apply within each paradigm even in the case where multiple paradigms coexist within a scientific field.

The only crucial difference between Kuhn’s account of a single paradigm and an account in which multiple paradigms coexist in a mature science pertains to the period of extraordinary science—specifically, the resolution of crises. To elaborate, in the case where multiple paradigms coexist within a scientific field, when critical anomalies arise and precipitate a crisis within a focal paradigm, the crisis may then be resolved in one of three ways: (a) the focal paradigm may resolve its anomalies in time to come; (b) the crisis may lead to revolution, and a new paradigm may emerge to overthrow the focal paradigm; or (c) researchers working within the focal paradigm may just switch to a more promising paradigm that already exists. Kuhn’s (1962, 1970a) work has already covered the former two ways. Extending Kuhn’s framework to include multiple paradigms within a mature scientific field thus offers one additional way in which a crisis may be resolved. However, this additional way will not change our argument that meta-analysis contributes to extraordinary science mainly by bringing to researchers an awareness of the persistent anomalies within their paradigm, which may then precipitate crises and revolutions for the focal paradigm. In sum, despite this major critique of Kuhn’s (1962, 1970b) work, the use of his framework to inform our understanding of how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth and scientific progress is still appropriate.

Indeed, in applying Kuhn’s (1962) framework to understanding how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth in a field, we have assumed that psychology is in the paradigmatic science stage (contrary to Kuhn’s viewpoint). Some readers may take issue with this assumption and argue that based on Kuhn’s binary demarcation of immature versus mature science, because the field of psychology contains more than one paradigm at a given moment, psychology is in the pre-paradigmatic stage and should thus be deemed an immature science (Warren, 1972). However, there are others who argue that with the birth of the mentalism paradigm (which focuses on the study of the mind and consciousness, with introspection as one of its main methodologies) in the late nineteenth century, psychology had transited into the paradigmatic, mature science stage (Kirsch, 1977). Moreover, the paradigms that have governed research in psychology exhibit many of Kuhn’s (1962) characterizations of research that occurs in the normal science period of a mature scientific field. That is, except for the fact that psychology does not have a single dominant paradigm in the field at a time, the way in which psychologists practice science very much corresponds to Kuhn’s (1970b) own notion of normal science. Therefore, psychology can be a multiparadigmatic science without being a pre-paradigmatic or immature science (contrary to Kuhn’s point of view).2 In light of these arguments, we consider it appropriate to adopt Kuhn’s (1962) framework—albeit with some modification (as we have made herein)—to understand how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth within each paradigm and in the overall scientific field.

More to the point, what is important to our discussion of how meta-analysis contributes to knowledge growth is that within each paradigm, (a) meta-analysis contributes to the main aim of research, which is to increase the precision and scope of the paradigm; and (b) meta-analysis also reveals and makes salient anomalous findings within the paradigm and thus contributes to its refinement or displacement. By contributing to the progress of both normal and extraordinary science, meta-analysis plays an important role in the growth of knowledge and the progress of psychological science.

In addition, some paradigms are especially influential in certain subdisciplines within psychology. For example, a paradigm that is especially central to social and organizational psychology is Lewin’s (1936) proposition that human behavior is determined by person and environment factors: B = f(P, E).

The nature of scientific research practice in psychology suggests that psychology may not be an immature science. First, the paradigms that have governed research in psychology exhibit many of Kuhn’s (1962) characterizations of research that occurs in the normal science period of a mature scientific field. For example, as illustrated earlier, the behaviorism and cognitivism paradigms each have their own respective beliefs, goals, language, and methodology—all of which are characteristics of paradigm-based research that feature in normal science (Kuhn, 1962). Second, Kuhn (1962, 1970b) noted that one of the main features that distinguished a pre-paradigmatic, immature science from a paradigmatic, mature science is that whereas the former involves debates among the competing schools of thought about the fundamentals of the field, the latter is characterized by the scarcity of such debates so that research progresses efficiently. Using this criterion, it seems that psychology may not be in the pre-paradigmatic, immature science stage. The following example serves to illustrate our point: Historians of psychology have noted that after the shift in paradigm from behaviorism to cognitivism occurred in mainstream psychology, a period of normal science ensued. This period of normal science, with cognitivism as the dominant paradigm in mainstream psychology (even until today), saw little debate about the fundamentals and assumptions in the psychology field. Indeed, Leahey (2004) noted that “by 1967, Neisser could write that ‘a generation ago a book like this one would have needed at least a chapter of self-defence against the behaviorist position. Today, happily, the climate of opinion has changed and little or no defense is necessary,’ because psychologists have come to accept ‘the familiar parallel between man and computer’” (p. 424). That there is little debate about the fundamentals in the field and that researchers do not feel the need to justify and establish first principles repeatedly before publishing their works suggest that psychology is in the normal science phase. Thus, except for the fact that psychology does not have a single dominant paradigm in the field at a time, the way in which psychologists practice science very much corresponds to Kuhn’s (1970b) own notion of normal science. In other words, if we are to conceive of scientific immaturity–maturity on a continuum (rather than adopt Kuhn’s binary conception of maturity), few would claim that psychology is an immature science. Last, what then shall we make of the fact that there are multiple paradigms in the psychology field? As mentioned earlier, one of the major criticisms against Kuhn’s (1962) work is that even for the mature sciences, more than one paradigm may be guiding the research activities in the scientific field at any given moment. Indeed, won’t this criticism release psychology from the burden of having to possess only a single dominant paradigm at a time in order for it to be considered a mature science? That is, if we are to take this major criticism seriously, then it seems appropriate to argue that psychology can be a multiparadigmatic science without being a pre-paradigmatic or immature science (contrary to Kuhn’s point of view).
